awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Mechanism of Protein Catalyzed Membrane Fusion
awd_abstract_narration:
CAREER: Mechanism of Protein Catalyzed Membrane Fusion
PI:Lorieau, Justin 

The fusion and poration of membranes underlies many fundamental processes in biology, including interaction of viruses with their hosts, neurotransmission and vesicle trafficking. This project aims to determine the mechanism of membrane fusion at the molecular level. The PI will use the prototypic influenza hemagglutinin fusion protein to understand membrane fusion during viral infection and cellular entry. The results of this project will reveal how proteins mediate membrane fusion and answer important questions on viral infection. These results will lead to important insights into a variety of viral infection mechanisms, as well as enhance our knowledge of fundamental processes in biological membranes. The educational aspects of the project integrates graduate students, undergraduates and research experiments in the classroom with molecular techniques in modern biophysics.

Membrane fusion will be studied by investigating the vital fusion peptide (HAfp) and transmembrane (HAtmd) domains of the influenza hemagglutinin. These domains are highly conserved and necessary for influenza membrane fusion and cellular entry. Yet, their molecular structures, impact on membranes, and intermolecular interactions remain poorly understood. The PI has made important advances in producing full-length, fully functional HAfp proteins as well as developed new techniques in NMR to determine how proteins impact membranes. With these advances, the PI will investigate 1) features in the HAfp structure that enhance early fusion activity, 2) changes in membrane structure and lipid dynamics by HAfp peptides, and 3) the protein-protein interactions necessary for pore formation late in the membrane fusion process.  A multi-pronged biophysical approach will be used, including molecular structure determination by NMR, calorimetry of membranes, fluorescence spectroscopy, mass spectrometry, analytic ultracentrifugation and size-exclusion chromatography.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Viral membrane fusion is the process by which enveloped viruses, like influenza, measles, Ebola and COVID-19, enter cells to infect them. This research grant supported the research program with 5 PhD graduate students and had intellectual merit in elucidating the mechanism of viral membrane fusion with the influenza virus and COVID-19. Using mutations and studying changes in molecular structure and functional activity, we have identified the mechanism of the influenza fusion peptide domain. We found that the crucial influenza fusion domain functions by stabilizing high-energy and high-curvature fusion intermediates. These insights could spur the development of new universal vaccines and pharmaceuticals that can treat all viral subtypes and obviate seasonal vaccinations. With solution NMR, we have identified the functional regions and secondary structure of the influenza hemagglutinin transmembrane domain and the COVID-19 fusion peptide sequence. This research advanced new methods to study membrane viral proteins, including the development of new membrane mimetic environments to study protein structure and super-resolution NMR methods to study more complex membrane and viral proteins.

This grant had broader impacts in supporting the research and dissertations of 5 PhD graduate students, in the development of a new course in Biophysical Spectroscopy, and in supporting new research infrastructure. The Biophysical Spectroscopy course focuses on practical aspects of biochemical and biophysical spectroscopic research, and it has helped undergraduate and graduate students apply these concepts in their future research and employment careers. Improvements to infrastructure include biochemistry, chromatographic and spectroscopic equipment, which has given students new opportunities to work with modern techniques and instrumentation.

 


Last Modified: 06/29/2023
Modified by: Justin Lorieau
